result.execSummary:
The defendant Trevor A Riedel was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer [Modifiers: Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.
Obtain and maintain employment.  Not to terminate employment without his agent's prior approval.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.

Defendant shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, or by any other means, with Jason Carroll.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Defendant to establish a stable residence approved by his agent.

Defendant to be subject to random drug testing by his agent.

Credit for 77 days, if revoked.

Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appeared on behalf of the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Roush.  Parties have the revocation packet.  No corrections or changes noted.  No victims.  State recommended:  1 year jail, all counts concurrent.  Defense recommended:  9 months jail, all counts concurrent.  93 days credit on each.  16CM59 an additional 77 days credit.  Defendant exercised his right to allocution.

Court ordered:  1 year jail, all counts concurrent.  Judgment for unpaid court ordered financial obligations.  93 days credit on each.  In 16CM59 an additional 77 days credit for a total credit of 170 days on that case.  Eligible for CIP and SAP if he is sentence to prison in another case.

Sentencing hearing on revocation on March 29, 2018 at 09:00 am.

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: DNA submission form.

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Sebion.  15CM250 plead no contest to Count 1.  15CM251 plead no contest to Count 1.  15CM315 Count 1, no contest plea.  16CM59 plead no contest to Count 1.  Any other charges are dismissed, but read in for sentencing purposes.   Court recited the charge and possible penalties on the counts he plead to.  Defendant understood. Repeater allegations confirmed with the defendant and Attorney Sebion. Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, and intelligently entered his pleas and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the pleas.  Found guilty of Obstructing contrary to 946.41(1) X3 and Poss. drug para. contrary to 961.573(1).  Joint recommendation for  2 years probation.  Concurrent.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  Seek and maintain employment.  

Court ordered:  sentence withheld, 2 years probation. Concurrent.  The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  Obtain and maintain employment.  Not to terminate without agent's prior approval.    Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  Establish a stable residence approved by his agent.  Subject to random drug testing.  No contact with Jason Carroll.   Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.  CC.  77 days credit on 16CM59, if revoked.
Plea/sentencing hearing on June 27, 2016 at 01:30 pm.

SPD Carly Sebion appears on behalf of the defendant.  Gerald Fox appears for the State.  Attorney Sebion will have all pending cases set for plea/sentencing on a day other than a Monday.  Sebion to schedule.
